abstract_summ: In view of this tug-of-war between one's privacy and public safety, this work aims to deepen the understanding of privacy risks of contact trace data disclosure practices in South Korea.Our results suggest that apps using a centralized architecture with strong security protection to do basic contact tracing and providing users with other useful information such as hotspots of infection in public places may achieve a high adoption rate in the U.S.Introduction: With the COVID-19 outbreak, South Korea has been making contact trace data public to help people self-check if they have been in contact with a person infected with the coronavirus.Despite its benefits in suppressing the spread of the virus, publicizing contact trace data raises concerns about individuals' privacy.The implementation of digital contact tracing applications around the world to help reduce the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic represents one of the most ambitious uses of massive-scale citizen data ever attempted.The lack of a consensus on privacy protection in the contact tracing process creates risks of non-compliance or deliberate obfuscation from citizens who fear revealing private aspects of their lives – a factor greatly exacerbated by recent major scandals over online privacy and the illicit use of citizens’ digital information, which have heightened public consciousness of these issues and created significant new challenges for any collection of large-scale public data.
title_summ: Towards Formal Definitions -- and Documented Understanding -- of Privacy Goals and Claimed Protection in Proximity-Tracing ServicesSocial Distancing 2.0 with Privacy-Preserving Contact Tracing to Avoid a Second Wave of COVID-19Decentralized is not risk-free: Understanding public perceptions of privacy-utility trade-offs in COVID-19 contact-tracing appsToo Much Information: Assessing Privacy Risks of Contact Trace Data Disclosure on People With COVID-19 in South KoreaCOVID-19, digital privacy, and the social limits on data-focused public health responsesReporting, Recording and Communication of COVID-19 Cases in Workplace: Data Protection as a Moving TargetContact tracing apps and values dilemmas: A privacy paradox in a neo-liberal worldCOVID-19 Contact Tracing Apps: A Stress Test for Privacy, the GDPR and Data Protection RegimesPersonal data usage and privacy considerations in the COVID-19 global pandemic.COVID-19 Contact Tracing: Eight Privacy Questions ExploredTrading Privacy for the Greater Social Good:How Did America React During COVID-19?Covid Notions:
title_abstract_phrases: COVID-19, digital privacy, and the social limits on data-focused public health responsesThe implementation of digital contact tracing applications around the world to help reduce the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic represents one of the most ambitious uses of massive-scale citizen data ever attempted.Our results suggest that apps using a centralized architecture with strong security protection to do basic contact tracing and providing users with other useful information such as hotspots of infection in public places may achieve a high adoption rate in the U.S.Too Much Information: Assessing Privacy Risks of Contact Trace Data Disclosure on People With COVID-19 in South KoreaIntroduction: With the COVID-19 outbreak, South Korea has been making contact trace data public to help people self-check if they have been in contact with a person infected with the coronavirus.In addition, the intricacies of different settings where such apps may be used should be taken into consideration when assessing the associated risks and benefits.The lack of a consensus on privacy protection in the contact tracing process creates risks of non-compliance or deliberate obfuscation from citizens who fear revealing private aspects of their lives – a factor greatly exacerbated by recent major scandals over online privacy and the illicit use of citizens’ digital information, which have heightened public consciousness of these issues and created significant new challenges for any collection of large-scale public data.In view of this tug-of-war between one's privacy and public safety, this work aims to deepen the understanding of privacy risks of contact trace data disclosure practices in South Korea.
